Spoke offline with Vinoth. Summarizing our discussion here. We want to see if we can do the same for MergeHandle or not. Here are my initial thoughts on this.
Merge Handle does 2 below operations

- Read records from Spark and add it to "keyToNewRecords". There is no benefit in parallelizing this operation.
- Read records from old parquet file and write it to new parquet file. I think there is some room here to optimize based on how much total time is spent in reading records from old parquet file vs total time spent in writing records to new parquet file. I will measure the timings and update it. If needed I will create another PR to handle MergeHandle use case.
lets continue this review, after we work through the perf issues as well..

@vinothchandar Moving Iterator to HoodieAvroDataBlock is tricky since there is no state maintained by HoodieAvroDataBlock and re-estimating record size is tricky. Also, at the moment, only DataBlocks get written by AppendHandle, if in the future, other types of datablocks are implemented, the logic in append handle can be common here ( another way would be to add this sizing operation as an operation to HoodieDataBlock and then Avro or any other data block just extends from that, but punting it right now, want to discuss this in the HoodieLogFormat V2 PR since that will require some refactoring of these LogBlocks anyways.) Added some results here. Let me know if that makes sense.

@vinothchandar in general, the shuffling happened because I imported the google_style xml again and formatted the code and realized this code wasn't conforming to the google style thingy.

The casting is done because the methods getCompactionWorkload() and handleCompaction() are table specific (that's sort of the case for such methods (handleUpdate(..) in COW table as well). I can move the stuff under getCompactionWorkload() to a WorkloadProfile constructor (just like for COW) but the handleCompaction(.) still remains.

@ovj this code actually already does that, the change is just to make sure we can get bytes before the stream is closed.

The reason we had it this way was to ensure that user can instantiate it on its own without the need to instantiate it using default constructor. Say if user partitioner needs extra parameters then we will have to pass it via hoodieConfig.

@kaushikd49 @ovj can you check if you can use the following new APIs in HoodieWriteClient:
`upsertPreppedRecords`, `insertPreppedRecords` and `bulkInsertPreppedRecords`?
@ovj & I spent a whole bunch of time on this and decided to go the current route..

@n3nash and @jianxu discussed this..  Opening up de-duplicate api makes the usage pretty unclean and decided that a client who decides to use one of prepped write client API, assumes responsibility for de-dup and tagging..
@vinothchandar @ovj thanks for the clarification, closing this then.
@bvaradar as well

@vinothchandar I see few ways to pass information of number of records needed in a partition to create handle : 
1) We can add this to the workload profile and call getpartitioner() before savingWorkloadProfile to the inflight file, but again, each executor will have to read the workload profile..
2) Expose a setter in the HoodieWriteConfig and set it there and pass it down..
3) Add it as another value to all method invokations leading to IOHandle..

I personally like 1 over 2 and am not in favor of 3. But I also want to explore the addition of the metric (this PR) which makes things simpler.
Thanks Vinoth, we will continue to replicate the dedup logic and revisit this if dedup logic changes frequently in future.
Thanks, Squashed commits @vinothchandar
@vinothchandar I've addressed your comments and left some more comments. Please take a pass. I'm going to do some microbenchmarking on the sizeEstimator in the meantime and report back

Can we on the fly detect if given rdd is already persisted or not and then persist it only if it is not done already may be using configs?
`
    public static Optional<RDDInfo> getRddInfo(@NonNull final SparkContext sc, final int rddId) {                       
        for (RDDInfo rddInfo : sc.getRDDStorageInfo()) {                                                                
            if (rddInfo.id() != rddId) {                                                                                
                continue;                                                                                               
            }                                                                                                           
            return Optional.of(rddInfo);                                                                                
        }                                                                                                               
        return Optional.absent();                                                                                       
    }  
`
